resources.string: CSCI-A 290: Android Application Interface, Design & Programming

My name is Matthew Lonis and I am a Junior at IU. My current degree I am pursuing is Computer Science with a specialization in Systems. I am also minoring in Math to better help with problem solving in computer science. My favorite hobbies are making music and playing video games. I also am an avid cat lover and love to have intellectual conversations with people. I can play all kinds of percussion instruments, bass guitar, piano, and make electronic music on my computer as well.

This app is intended to display my Android knowledge that I have aquired at IU\'s A290 Android course. The App features my resume, where you can zoom in and out to view it better, and a master/detail flow containing all my projects I have done while at IU. You will find clickable buttons to view my project source code on GitHub.

CSCI-C 211 is the first course in IU\'s computer science cirriculum. The course features an introduction to programming and to algorithm design & analysis. The course utilizes the Scheme programming language. The course aims to cover several programming paradigms.
This project required that I make a program in the Racket language that essentially mimicked the paint fill function in Microsoft Paint.

This project recreates a simple Tetris game in the Racket language. This game is very simple and does not feature a menu or any other sort of graphical interface other than the tetris board. The project features a hand-made big-bang.

This project recreates a paint program. The top menu bar features an assortment of colors the user can click on to change the color that they will be painting with. It also includes mouse and keyboard event handlers to change the size of the circle that is being painted as well as to undo and redo previous painting operations.

This project recreates the game 2048. This follows exactly like the game 2048 however you can choose the board size. There is also no animations during a board slide, however all the logic works out so that you can play the game like you would regular 2048.

CSCI-C 212 introduced me to the design of computer software systems and provided an introduction to programming in the environment of a contemporary operating system. The topics of this course included a modern object-oriented programming language (Java), building and maintaining large projects, and understanding the operating system interface.

This project recreates the game Tetris in Java. By clicking the link below you can view all the code for this project. All block shapes are implemented in their own separate .java files and all extend the Tetromino.java class.

CSCI-C 343 is a course where I conducted a systematic study of data structures encountered in computing problems, structure and use of storage media, methods of representing structured data, and techniques for operating on data structures.

In this project I learned how to implement a hash table, including multiple strategies for collision resolution, and then used my own hash table in an application for comparing images. The comparison of images is done by condensing the color spectrum to a bit between 1-8 per channel. From there, colors there colors were added to my HashTable by associating a key (representing the color) with a frequency of occurences in a picture. From there we took the cosine similarity between two HashTables representing two different images and got a value between 0 and 1 (0 being not similar at all and 1 being identical).

CSCI-C 291 teaches students to programming in a Unix (Linux) environment using the C language. The key ideas discussed in this course are: the Unix shell, file system and basic shell commands, the emacs text editor, and the C programming language.

This project required that I make a program in the C language that allows a user to utilize operations (operations.c) such as add elements, insert elements, and search for a number in a linked list. The user is given a command prompt menu in order to implement these operations (client.c). The use of a Node header (node.h) is also included in each of these files.
CSCI-A 290 explores various topics in computing. C & UNIX Basic covers an introduction to the C programming langauge and the UNIX operating system.
This project showcases a C program that allows a user to use a menu and manipulate a linked list.
CSCI-A 290 explores various topics in computing. Windows Programming with C# & .NET introduces students to programming Windows application with C# in Visual Studio.
This project showcases a Windows application that includes many different Views that allow the user to use a calculator, tire size calculator & comparison, and use a unit converter to name a few.

CSCI-A 290 explores various topics in computing. Android Application Interface, Design & Programming introduces students to the design and interface of Android applications as well as hands-on experience to programming an Android application.
This project is the app you are currently viewing. I wanted to display my understanding of Android, app design, and fluent navigation.

Problem solving with information technology; introductions to information representation, relational databases, system design, propositional logic, cutting-edge technologies: CPU, operation systems, networks; laboratory emphasizing information technology including Web page design, word processing, databases, using tools available on campus.
For this project I created a personal website using bootstrap. The website features information about me, my resume, and projects I have completed throughout my time at IU.
